how can i configure ubuntu so that every time i type sudo apt-get i dont have to go sudo su first?
you add your user with the NOPASSWD option to /etc/sudoers. see "man sudoers" for more info and correct syntax
that is, if you want the user to execute apt-get without being asked for a password. all users in "admin" group should be able to use "sudo apt-get" and is then asked for password.
that does not make sence to me. "sudo su" would give you a root prompt, in which case you don't need to use sudo at all.
have you by any chance copied over old /etc/... files from the old ubuntu install?
sudo apt-get install nvidiblabla && sudo dpkg-reconfigure... the lock error usually means that apt is busy (you might have synaptic package manager or aptitude open already=
on previous installation i could install multiple apt-get at same time in seperate terminal windows
that is not possible nowadays due to that there can be corruption in the apt cache (or something similar. that's why there is a lock used now)
bitmap, ddc, dri, extmod, freetype, glx, int10, vbe should be enough
